description: As a child you spent hours retrieving and cataloging priority, and you have become quite good at it. tomes and scrolls for older scholars who left you to your own Youth: As a child, you spent the majority of your days either devices once they had the materials they sought. Spending on the road or performing odd jobs and running errands for your these hours with little supervision, you learned the location of elders. You put any talents you had to work for you just to get by nearly every work stored in the library of the mountain abbey and perhaps earn a little food or a few spare coins. You might have you called home. While at that age you couldn’t fathom the turned to crime when things became desperate, or you might mysteries stored within, you kept a mental tally of those that have resisted all temptation no matter how bad things got. 131 IDENTITY BUILDING YOUR CHAPTER 5 You could have ended up on the road due to a number of every aspect of farm life and grew to appreciate the hard work reasons. You left behind generations of tradition to your mother’s back and then later walking beside her. seek the adventuring life. Whether you were pushed into this
name: Perhaps you grew up in an orphanage and ran away as soon as you Transition

description: As a child, you hung upon the apron strings of those older, more experienced gladiators. Given your innate sense working in the home and hearth. You learned to clean the of dramatic fl air, you have come to enjoy the adulation of the dwelling in which you lived, as well as cook for those who lived crowd, as well as the respect of your peers. there with you. As you grew older, your daily chores became Youth: Your daily routine began with a strict regimen of more complicated and laborious. From splitting and hauling calisthenics followed by training in the pits. Every hour you fi rewood, feeding and cleaning up after the animals, and working trained with a different master, each focusing on different the earth to produce the crops you need to live on, you learned methods of fi ghting and teaching you ways to present yourself 132 5 RETPAHC RUOY GNIDLIUB YTITNEDI with a distinct theatrical air. After a noon meal, you were set victories. When you face a problem, violence is your preferred to sparring in the arena, focusing on different tactics and solution (soft words and subtle methods never served you well in scenarios—some meant for the individual and some done the arena). Politics are beyond you. There’s no obstacle that can’t in pairs, each gladiator working in tandem with another. be overcome with a swift blow to the head. When it comes time
name: Youth

description: Cleric, druid, favored soul, knight, marshal, monk, AGENT paladin, wizard. “It shall be as you command.” Traits: Bold, patriotic, religious. An agent adventures not for herself but for an orga- nization or society, whether a thieves guild sends her to DAREDEVIL gather information, she explores new territory for an em- “You guys stay here. I’m going to scale the wall, sneak past the guards, peror, or she carries the name of her deity into new lands. swim the moat, have a look around, and come back.” An agent might be loyal to her organization, or she might A daredevil gets a rush from dangerous stunts. He is a risk- resent her role and look for a way to escape. An agent can taker and a gambler, willing to put his money, his reputation, create interesting dynamics in an adventuring party, espe- and his life at stake purely for exhilaration. description: Brutal, exotic, naïve. SEEKER “Let us press on. The White Staff could be in that cave.” A seeker adventures because he is look- ing for something, often an object or an individual. The object of his quest might be specifi c (the White Staff of the Grimalkin) or general (a way to stop the disease in his home village). He grudgingly participates in adventures that do not pertain directly to his quest, but the object or individual he seeks gives him focus and provides motivation for further adventures. When his allies join him on his adventures, a seeker provides contin- ued impetus for additional adventures.
name: Traits

description: Barbarian, cleric, dragon shaman, duskblade, favored soul, fi ghter, knight, monk, ranger, scout, sorcerer, wizard.

description: Flamboyant, funny. out tremendous punishment as quickly as possible to vent your temper. WANDERER “I have no home. I have no family. I have no name.” BOASTFUL A wanderer is a mysterious soul. She keeps her past to herself “How do you like that, huh? Want some more?” and doesn’t talk much. Perhaps something horrible happened You’re a showoff. You gloat about your accomplishments to her when she was younger. Perhaps she committed an unfor- and disparage your enemies—calling them names, making givable crime, or was accused of a crime she didn’t commit. rude gestures, and otherwise taunting them. 141 IDENTITY BUILDING YOUR CHAPTER 5
name: Traits

description: You lead from the front. Unless a rogue or CONNECTED ranger scouts ahead, you want to be at the forefront of any “You’d better not be insulting my sister.” attack. You charge the foe in battle to bring the fi ght to him. In You have a historical connection with one of the other your mind, the key to victory lies in seizing momentum. Feats party members. You might be siblings, childhood friends, such as Improved Initiative refl ect your aggressive attitude. or fellow students of the same master. You might like each other, or you might not; it’s also possible that one or both BRUTAL of you is unaware of your connection. Perhaps one of you “He surrendered? Sorry, I didn’t hear it; I was too busy chopping was sent to protect the other or otherwise keep an eye off his head.” on her.
name: At the Table

description: When the group faces a problem, you invari- them until they stop moving. ably fi nd someone who can help you. When you enter a tavern,
name: You show little mercy to your enemies, preferring to hit At the Table

description: When facing a badly injured foe, use a free SERIOUS action to offer it the option to surrender. Ready an attack to “How can you think of dancing at a time like this?” strike if it keeps fi ghting you. You take everything seriously and have little or no sense of humor. NAÏVE At the Table: You grumble when others make jokes or venture “Why is that person angry at me?” off topic. During a planning session, you are the one who calls You are inexperienced and perhaps led a sheltered exis- for order and keeps things organized. Invest a few ranks in tence before becoming an adventurer. You sometimes make Knowledge skills to give you the experience and insight needed mistakes because you don’t know any better, but you mean to back up your demand for focus and careful planning. well, and your naïveté lends you a certain charm.
name: At the Table

Since the numbers keep track of the time—either count up for the total duration and names that summarize your character’s abilities will or count down for time remaining; at the start of your turn each change over the course of your character’s career, and even round, turn the die to the next number. Be careful, though, during specifi c adventures or rounds, you want to be able to that you don’t accidentally roll this “duration die.” mark the changes on your character sheet. While some of this sort of activity is fun, and rub an old scar on her neck every so often? All these types of you play D&D to have fun, don’t let the entire session pass behavior make your character seem more like a real person. in idle banter or witty repartee—especially if some players Many D&D campaigns begin with strong player are not partaking in it. characters—they have interesting histories, developed In general, keep your attention focused on the game. Your personalities, and distinctive appearances. However, often fellow players might think you rude if you leave the table to these valuable details fade over the course of adventuring. surf the Internet or play video games, or if you distract other Players are pretty good at remembering their own characters, players with side conversations. but they sometimes forget the histories, appearances, names,
name: Avoid Distractions

description: Inevitably, characters (and their players) come into team can derive a benefi t simply from having their comrades confl ict during the game. The dispute might be about who nearby. This teamwork benefi t can grant an expanded use gets a certain piece of treasure, or it might be a disagreement of a skill, a bonus on certain checks, or a battlefi eld action over a proposed course of action. When such a confl ict occurs, otherwise unavailable to the team members. it’s wise to put a time limit on the ensuing debate so that it To qualify for a teamwork benefi t, PCs must meet two broad cannot derail the game session. Furthermore, a disinterested categories of requirements: training time and prerequisites. character (or player) should listen to all sides of the argument First, the characters must jointly practice techniques relevant and make a binding decision. This “judge” role can fall to dif- to the desired benefi t for at least two weeks before acquiring it. ferent characters depending on who is involved in the debate, This training period must be repeated whenever a new character but someone who can make a quick decision and resolve the joins the group, so that the newcomer can become accustomed argument is invaluable for keeping the game on track. to the operating procedures of the veteran team members.
name: Judge

description: A brief discussion of the training procedure Teamwork benefi ts are based on the notion that once charac- required to acquire the benefi t. The task leader coordinates ters have spent time training with their comrades, they can the training. respond instinctively to subtle changes in body language and Task Leader Prerequisite: A base attack bonus, a feat anticipate their teammates’ likely moves. A group of PCs or or feats, a minimum number of ranks in one or more skills, a class feature, or some other requirement that at least one character on the team must have for the team to acquire this pqs benefi t. This entry is absent if a teamwork benefi t has no task leader prerequisite. If a benefi t has more than one task leader HANDLE ANIMAL prerequisite, the same character must meet all of them for (NEW TRICK: TEAMWORK) the team to gain that benefi t.
